raw_text:
Xbox 2 may be unveiled in summer
 
 Details of the next generation of Microsoft's Xbox games console - codenamed Xenon - will most likely be unveiled in May, according to reports.
 
 It was widely expected that gamers would get a sneak preview of Xbox's successor at the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in March. But a Microsoft spokeswoman confirmed that it would not be at GDC. Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo are all expected to release their more powerful machines in the next 18 months. The next Xbox console is expected to go on sale at the end of the year, but very few details about it have been released. It is thought that the machine may be unveiled at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles, which takes place in May, according to a Reuters news agency report. E3 concentrates on showing off the latest in gaming to publishers, marketers and retailers. The GDC is aimed more at game developers. Microsoft chief, Bill Gates, used the GDC event to unveil the original Xbox five years ago. Since its launch, Microsoft has sold 19.9 million units worldwide.
 
 At the Consumer Electronics Show earlier this year, there was very little mention of the next generation gaming machine. In his keynote speech, Mr Gates only referred to it as playing an essential part of his vision of the digital lifestyle.
 
 But the battle between the rival consoles to win gamers' hearts and thumbs will be extremely hard-fought. Sony has traditionally dominated the console market with its PlayStation 2. But earlier this year, Microsoft said it had reached a European milestone, selling five million consoles since its European launch in March 2002. Hit games like Halo 2, which was released in November, helped to buoy the sales figures.
 
 Gamers are looking forward to the next generation of machines because they will have much more processing and graphical power.
 
 They are also likely to pack in more features and technologies that make them more central as entertainment and communications hubs. Although details of PlayStation 3, Xenon, and Nintendo's so-called Revolution, are yet to be finalised, developers are already working on titles. Rory Armes, studio general manager for games giant Electronic Arts (EA) in Europe, recently told the BBC News website in an interview that EA was beginning to get a sense of the capabilities of the new machines. Microsoft had delivered development kits to EA, but he said the company was still waiting on Sony and Nintendo's kits. But, he added, the PlayStation 3 was rumoured to have "a little more under the hood [than Xbox 2]".
llama3.2:1b: Microsoft is expected to unveil its next-generation console, codenamed Xenon, in May at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles. The unveiling will be a departure from Microsoft's previous GDC announcement, which failed to generate significant hype due to limited details about the product.
llama3.2:3b: Xbox 2 may be unveiled in May at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, with a possible release date at the end of the year, ahead of Sony's PlayStation 3 and Nintendo's Revolution. The next generation console is expected to have significant processing and graphical power upgrades.
gemma2:2b: The next generation of Microsoft's Xbox console (codename Xenon) is expected to be unveiled in May at E3.  Details remain scarce, but it's anticipated to launch by year's end.  The competition between Microsoft, Sony, and Nintendo for the gaming market will be intense, with each company focusing on more powerful processors, advanced features, and role as entertainment hubs.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The next generation of Microsoft's Xbox games console is expected to go on sale in the first half of 2016. The latest generation of consoles, codenamed Xenon, will be unveiled at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles later in the year. Developers are already working on titles for the new machines, although details remain finalised. The Xbox 2 was widely expected to become a significant part of the console lineup due to its potential upgrade capabilities and processing power. While Microsoft has promised it will be less powerful than its previous console, it is still uncertain how much more powerful the next generation of consoles will be.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The next generation of Xbox console, codenamed Xenon, is expected to be unveiled in May at E3, likely replacing its rival consoles from Sony and Nintendo. Microsoft aims for widespread release by the end of the year, with a detailed preview planned for GDC in March 2015. Xbox's launch coincides with intense competition among major game developers.
qwen2.5:3b: Xbox 2 may be unveiled in May as part of Microsoft’s next-generation gaming console, codenamed Xenon. This follows expectations that it would debut at the Game Developers Conference but not E3, where Sony and Nintendo are also expected to showcase their new machines. The Xbox is anticipated to go on sale by year-end. Major features include enhanced processing and graphical power, along with more entertainment and communication functionalities. While details of Xenon and competing consoles like PlayStation 3 and Nintendo’s Revolution are still forthcoming, development work on titles for these systems has begun.

tinyllama:1.1b: In a recent report from Reuters, Microsoft CEO Bill Gate is expected to unveil the next generation of its popular Xbox gaming console at the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles in May. However, despite the company's claim of showing off the latest in gaming technology, there have been few details about the upcoming machine released earlier this year. Microsoft is expected to showcase its next-generation machine, which was rumored to have "a little more under the hood" than the current Xbox 2, at the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in March, which will take place in San Francisco. The company's game developers are eagerly awaiting the new machines' release as they prepare to launch hit games like "Halo 2" and "Halo 3," which were both relased in November, driving sales figures for Sony's PlayStation 2. Developers are already working on titles for the next-generation machines, with EA studio general manager Roys Armes saying that Microsoft had delivered development kits to EA but has yet to receive a "real" kernel from the company.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In May, Microsoft is expected to unveil its next-generation gaming console - codenamed Xenon - at the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in San Francisco. It was widely anticipated that gamers would get a sneak peek of this machine during GDC. However, Microsoft confirmed that it will not be at GDC. Instead, the company is expected to reveal the next Xbox console in May at an event called Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) in Los Angeles. This expo is aimed more at game developers and will take place from June 15-17th, 2008. It was there that Microsoft first unveiled the original Xbox five years ago. Since its launch, Xbox has sold over 19.9 million units worldwide.

Sony's PlayStation 2 has traditionally dominated the market, but Microsoft sold 5 million consoles in Europe since its launch in March 2002. Game developers, publishers, marketers, and retailers attend E3, while game developers primarily go to the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in March.

Microsoft's chief, Bill Gates, last unveiled the original Xbox at GDC five years ago, since then selling 19.9 million units worldwide.

The competition intensifies as Sony prepares its PlayStation 3 and Nintendo its Revolution (codenamed "Revolution"). Microsoft's European sales reached five million consoles following launch in March 2002, partly due to successful titles like Halo 2. Developers are already preparing games for these consoles, with EA's Rory Armes reporting that while Microsoft has delivered development kits, Sony and Nintendo's are still to come. PlayStation 3 is rumored to have "a little more under the hood" than Xenon.

reference: Details of the next generation of Microsoft's Xbox games console - codenamed Xenon - will most likely be unveiled in May, according to reports.The next Xbox console is expected to go on sale at the end of the year, but very few details about it have been released.At the Consumer Electronics Show earlier this year, there was very little mention of the next generation gaming machine.It was widely expected that gamers would get a sneak preview of Xbox's successor at the Game Developers Conference (GDC) in March.Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo are all expected to release their more powerful machines in the next 18 months.Microsoft chief, Bill Gates, used the GDC event to unveil the original Xbox five years ago.But earlier this year, Microsoft said it had reached a European milestone, selling five million consoles since its European launch in March 2002.Microsoft had delivered development kits to EA, but he said the company was still waiting on Sony and Nintendo's kits.But a Microsoft spokeswoman confirmed that it would not be at GDC.
